Wallemia ichthyophaga EXF-994 is a species of halophilic (salt-loving) fungus that belongs to the phylum Basidiomycota. It is a member of the genus Wallemia, which is known for its ability to thrive in high-salt environments.

This particular strain, EXF-994, was isolated from a hypersaline environment, such as a salt lake or saltern. Wallemia ichthyophaga is characterized by its small, globose (spherical) fruiting bodies and the production of small, unicellular spores called ballistospores, which are forcibly discharged and dispersed by air currents.

The species is known to be xerophilic (drought-tolerant) and can grow in environments with very low water activity, such as high-salt or high-sugar conditions. This adaptation allows it to survive in harsh, saline environments where other fungi might not be able to thrive.

Wallemia ichthyophaga EXF-994 has been studied for its potential applications in biotechnology, such as the production of enzymes or other metabolites that could be useful in various industrial processes. Its ability to grow under extreme conditions makes it an interesting model organism for studying the mechanisms of adaptation and survival in extreme environments.
